I think Iâ€™m not alone in saying that the excitement of last weekâ€™s brilliantÂ Tour de SuisseÂ left me wanting more â€” more stages, and more races on the calendar overall. It was truly a nail-biting race that came down to just one second and a real showcase of how gripping womenâ€™s racing is when we get to watch it live.Â 

By the time theÂ 2.1 Lotto Belgium TourÂ comes around on the 22nd weâ€™ll have gone more than two weeks without live racing. Sure, there are a million national championship races coming up (some of which will be broadcast live, but more on that next week) but itâ€™s not quite the same, is it? Then, thereâ€™s everyoneâ€™s favourite sideshow in the form of the next WWT race,Â La Course,on the 26th which was â€” for reasons of sexismâ€” moved a day forward due to local elections (while the menâ€™s TdF stage on the same day in the same place stayed in tact.)Â 

Anyway rather than end on that note, hereâ€™s a preview of this weekâ€™s news and content which includes; a game of Team Staff Musical Chairs, the USA Olympic team selection, an update to WWT team regulations, and further details on those promising ethics updates from everyoneâ€™s favourite governing body. Scroll down for more!

NewsÂ ğŸ“°

  • Last week we heard thatÂ Lars BoomÂ would be leaving his role asÂ Liv Racingâ€™s Performance Manager immediately after he signed up to work for another team in 2022. That team isâ€¦SD WorxÂ â€” where star rideÂ Lotte KopeckyÂ happens to be going next season, too. The team said in aÂ press releaseÂ that Boom would be coaching Hungarian cyclocross riderÂ Kata Blanka VasÂ during the winter before moving into a technical staff role from the 1st January 2022 where he will work alongsideÂ Anna van der BreggenÂ andÂ Chantal van den Broek Blaakin their new behind-the-scenes roles.

Dygert,Â Megan Jastrab,Â Lily Williams, andÂ Emma WhiteÂ will make up the team pursuit squad on the track while Maddie Godby will contest the Keirin.Â Payton Ridenour,Â Felicia Stancil,Â Alise WilloughbyÂ will race BMX.Â Perris BenegasÂ andÂ Hannah RobertsÂ will race BMX freestyle.Â 
  • In other selection newsÂ Â Valerie Demey,Â Lotte Kopecky, andÂ Julie Van de VeldeÂ will representÂ BelgiumÂ in the road race and Van de Velde will also race the time trial.Â Githa MichielsÂ will race MTB andÂ Elke VanhoofÂ BMX. The track selection will be announced on the 3rd of July.
  • Afghan riderÂ Masomah Ali ZadaÂ was selected as part of the IOC Refugee Olympic Team to race the ITT at the Tokyo Games on the 28th July.
  • Team Uno-XÂ have revealedÂ that they will apply forÂ Womenâ€™s WorldTeamÂ status for 2022. They will be able to do thisÂ via a loophole in the UCI regulationsÂ that was updated this week in which new teams will be able to enter at WWT level if fewer than 15 existing WWT or Continental teams apply.

Writing from an altitude camp in Andorra she did confirm, however, that she will be racing the Dutch national championships in both the time trial and the road race before she heads back for another block of altitude â€” this time in Italy.

Results ğŸ†

  • Has everyone stopped holding their breath after stage two of theÂ Tour de Suisse womenÂ last weekend? Iâ€™ve coveredÂ a full breakdown of what happened, so check that out if you want more detailÂ but it was great to see such a tactical race that came down to bonus seconds.Elise ChabbeyÂ ofÂ Canyon//SRAMÂ took the first stage, out-sprintingÂ Lizzie DeignanÂ ofÂ Trek-SegafredoÂ after forcing her into going early when the two came to the line together,Â Marlen ReusserÂ (Ale BTC Ljubljana) took third 24â€ back.Â Going into the second and final stage Chabbeyâ€™s advantage stood at four seconds and Deignan and her Trek team made it their mission to line up their rider to take bonus seconds at the intermediate sprints. After both Canyon//SRAM and Trek-Segafredo tried every tactic in the book against each other it was Deignan who managed to claw back five seconds to win the race by one solitary second.Â Marta BastianelliofÂ Ale BTC LjubljanaÂ took the stage ahead ofÂ Tereza NeumanovaÂ ofÂ BurgosÂ andÂ Hannah BarnesÂ ofÂ Canyon//SRAM.Stage one highlightsÂ here. Stage two highlightsÂ here.

Rebecca McconnellÂ took second andÂ Jolanda NeffÂ third.Â Jenny Rissveds,Â Haley Batten,Â Pauline Ferrand Prevot,Â Sina Frei, andÂ Janika LiovÂ also earned front-row starts for Sundayâ€™s XCO race.
  • Leonie DaubermannÂ won theÂ German national XCOÂ title while her sisterÂ LuisaÂ took the U23 title.Â 
  • Dame Sarah StoreyÂ won the 39th world title of her career in Portugal at theÂ UCI Para-Cycling World ChampionshipsÂ taking gold in the WC5 25.2km time trial, fellow GB riderÂ Crystal Lane-WrightÂ took second and Germanyâ€™sÂ Kerstin BrachtendorfÂ third. More results and details on the Para-Cycling World Championships can be foundÂ here.

Most of those events are time trials with the road races happening next weekend.Â

The womenâ€™s XCO race is onÂ Sunday at 12:00 CEST. The downhill final isÂ 12:30 CESTÂ onÂ SaturdayÂ and you can watch it all live onÂ Red Bull TV.Â
